name: Kish Tablet
subject: unknown
description: The Kish tablet is a limestone tablet found at the site of the ancient Sumerian city of Kish in modern Tell al-Uhaymir, Babylon Governorate, Iraq. The signs on the Kish tablet, possibly related to proto-cuneiform, are purely pictographic, and have not been deciphered or demonstrated to correspond to human language.

name: Narmer Palette
subject: historical record
description: The tablet is thought by some to depict the unification of Upper and Lower Egypt under the king Narmer. Along with the Scorpion Macehead and the Narmer Maceheads, also found together in the main deposit at Nekhen, the Narmer Palette provides one of the earliest known depictions of an Egyptian king. On one side, the king is depicted with the bulbed White Crown of Upper (southern) Egypt, and the other side depicts the king wearing the level Red Crown of Lower (northern) Egypt, which also makes it the earliest known example of a king wearing both types of headdress. Egyptologists Bob Brier and A. Hoyt Hobbs have referred to the Narmer Palette as 'The oldest Egyptian historical record'.

name: Instructions of Shuruppak
subject: wisdom literature
description:
TheÂ Instructions ofÂ ShuruppakÂ (or,Â Instructions of Å uruppakÂ son of Ubara-tutu) are a significant example ofÂ SumerianÂ wisdom literature.[2]Â Wisdom literature, intended to teach proper piety, inculcateÂ virtue, and preserve community standards, was common throughout theÂ ancient Near East.Â ItsÂ incipitÂ sets the text in great antiquity: â€˜In those days, in those far remote times, in those nights, in those faraway nights, in those years, in those far remote years.â€™ The precepts are placed in the mouth of a king Å uruppak (SU.KUR.RUki), son ofÂ Ubara-Tutu. Ubara-Tutu is recorded in most extant copies of theÂ Sumerian King ListÂ as being the final king of Sumer prior to theÂ deluge. Ubara-tutu is briefly mentioned inÂ tablet XIÂ of theÂ Epic of Gilgamesh, where he is identified as the father ofÂ Utnapishtim, a character who is instructed by the godÂ EaÂ to build a boat in order to survive the coming flood.[4]Â Grouped with the otherÂ cuneiformÂ tablets fromÂ Abu Salabikh, theÂ InstructionsÂ date to the earlyÂ third millennium BCE, being among theÂ oldest surviving literature.

The text consists of admonitory sayings of Å uruppak addressed to his son and eventualÂ flood heroÂ ZiusudraÂ (Akkadian:Â Utnapishtin). Otherwise named as one of the five antediluvian cities in the Sumerian tradition,[5]Â the name â€˜Å uruppakâ€™ appears in one manuscript of theÂ Sumerian King ListÂ (WB-62, written SU.KUR.LAM) where it is interpolated as an additional generation between Ubara-Tutu and Ziusudra, who are in every other instance father and son. Lambert reports that it has been suggested the interpolation may have arisen through an epithet of the father (â€˜man of Shuruppakâ€™) having been taken wrongly for a proper name.Â However, this epithet, found in the GilgameshÂ XI tablet, is a designation applied to Utnapishtim, not his father.

name: Diary of Merer (Papyrus Jarf)
subject: diary
description: The Diary of Merer (also known as Papyrus Jarf) is the name for papyrus logbooks written over 4,500 years ago by Merer, a middle-ranking official with the title inspector (sá¸¥á¸, sehedj). They are the oldest known papyri with text, dating to the 26th year of the reign of Pharaoh Khufu (reigned in the early 26th century BC, estimated c. 2589 â€“ c. 2566 BC) during the Fourth Dynasty of Egypt. The text, written with (hieratic) hieroglyphs, mostly consists of lists of the daily activities of Merer and his crew. The best preserved sections (Papyrus Jarf A and B) document the transportation of white limestone blocks from the Tura quarries to Giza by boat.

name: Palermo Stone
subject: historical record
description: The Palermo Stone is one of seven surviving fragments of a stele known as the Royal Annals of the Old Kingdom of Ancient Egypt. The stele contained a list of the kings of Egypt from the First Dynasty (c. 3150â€“2890 BCE) through to the early part of the Fifth Dynasty (c. 2392â€“2283 BCE) and noted significant events in each year of their reigns. It was probably made during the Fifth Dynasty. The term 'Palermo Stone' is sometimes applied to all seven surviving fragments of the Royal Annals including those held in museums in Cairo and London. The fragments are also sometimes described collectively as the 'Cairo Annals Stone' although the term 'Cairo Stone' is also used to mean only those fragments of the Royal Annals now in Cairo.

name: Istanbul #2461
subject: love poem
description: Istanbul #2461 is an ancient Sumerian cuneiform tablet. Some have labelled it the world's oldest love poem. It is on display at the Istanbul Museum of the Ancient Orient (Mesopotamia Hall). It is an erotic poem addressed to king Shu-Sin (reigned 20th or 21st century BC) by an unnamed female speaker. It is thought that the poem may be connected to a 'sacred marriage' between the king and a priestess of Inanna.

name: Code of Hammurabi
period: Old Babylonian Empire (First Dynasty of Babylon)
subject: list of laws
description:
The Code of Hammurabi is a Babylonian legal text composed during 1755â€“1750 BC. It is the longest, best-organized, and best-preserved legal text from the ancient Near East. It is written in the Old Babylonian dialect of Akkadian, purportedly by Hammurabi, sixth king of the First Dynasty of Babylon. The primary copy of the text is inscribed on a basalt stele 2.25 m (7 ft 4+1â„2 in) tall.

The stele was rediscovered in 1901 at the site of Susa in present-day Iran, where it had been taken as plunder six hundred years after its creation. The text itself was copied and studied by Mesopotamian scribes for over a millennium. The stele now resides in the Louvre Museum.

The top of the stele features an image in relief of Hammurabi with Shamash, the Babylonian sun god and god of justice. Below the relief are about 4,130 lines of cuneiform text: one fifth contains a prologue and epilogue in poetic style, while the remaining four fifths contain what are generally called the laws. In the prologue, Hammurabi claims to have been granted his rule by the gods 'to prevent the strong from oppressing the weak'. The laws are casuistic, expressed as 'if ... then' conditional sentences. Their scope is broad, including, for example, criminal law, family law, property law, and commercial law.

name: Complaint tablet to Ea-nÄá¹£ir
subject: commercial complaint
description:
The complaint tablet to Ea-nÄá¹£ir (UET V 81)[1] is a clay tablet that was sent to the ancient city-state Ur, written c.â€‰1750 BCE. The tablet, measuring 11.6 cm high and 5 cm wide, documents a transaction in which Ea-nÄá¹£ir,[a] a trader, allegedly sold sub-standard copper to a customer named Nanni. Nanni, dissatisfied with the quality, wrote a cuneiform complaint addressing the poor service and mistreatment of his servant.

Written in Akkadian cuneiform, this tablet is recognized as the 'Oldest Customer Complaint' by Guinness World Records. From 2015 onwards, the tablet's content and Ea-nÄá¹£ir in particular gained popularity as an internet meme, due to its modern-sounding nature of dissatisfaction with goods.

name: The Gilgamesh Dream Tablet
subject: epic
description:
The Epic of Gilgamesh (/ËˆÉ¡ÉªlÉ¡É™mÉ›Êƒ/)[2] is an epic from ancient Mesopotamia. The literary history of Gilgamesh begins with five Sumerian poems about Gilgamesh (formerly read as Sumerian 'Bilgames'), king of Uruk, some of which may date back to the Third Dynasty of Ur (c.â€‰2100 BCE).[1] These independent stories were later used as source material for a combined epic in Akkadian. The first surviving version of this combined epic, known as the 'Old Babylonian' version, dates back to the 18th century BCE and is titled after its incipit, ShÅ«tur eli sharrÄ« ('Surpassing All Other Kings'). Only a few tablets of it have survived.

In the early 2000s, the Gilgamesh Dream Tablet was imported illegally into the United States. According to the United States Department of Justice, the tablet was encrusted with dirt and unreadable when it was purchased by a US antiquities dealer in 2003. The tablet was sold by an unnamed antiques dealer in 2007 with a letter falsely stating that it had been inside a box of ancient bronze fragments purchased in a 1981 auction. In 2014, Hobby Lobby privately purchased the tablet for display at the Museum of the Bible in Washington, D.C. In 2019, the Gilgamesh Dream Tablet was seized by US officials and was returned to Iraq in September 2021.

name: Akkadian Cuneiform in Jerusalem
subject: unknown
description:
A tiny clay fragment ï¿½ dating from the 14th century B.C.E. ï¿½ that was found in excavations outside Jerusalemï¿½s Old City walls contains the oldest written document ever found in Jerusalem, say researchers at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. The find, believed to be part of a tablet from a royal archives, further testifies to the importance of Jerusalem as a major city in the Late Bronze Age, long before its conquest by King David, they say.

The words the symbols form are not significant in themselves, but what is significant is that the script is of a very high level, testifying to the fact that it was written by a highly skilled scribe that in all likelihood prepared tablets for the royal household of the time, said Prof. Wayne Horowitz, a scholar of Assyriology at the Hebrew University Institute of Archaeology.

name: Vedas Palm Leaf Manuscript
subject: Hinduism
description:
The four layers of texts that make up the Vedas were composed between 1500 to 600 BCE. They are the oldest documented sacred literature of Hinduism. These were orally transmitted for centuries and likely written down sometime around the start of the common era. The above palm leaf manuscript pages are from Tamil Nadu India, in Grantha script, Sanskrit language. This manuscript is likely pre-17th century, but the exact year of its production is unknown. Such manuscripts were produced and preserved in Hindu temples.

On the Indian subcontinent, principal writing media wereÂ bhurjapatraÂ made fromÂ birch bark, andÂ palm leaf manuscript. Palm leaf manuscript was also the major source for writing and painting in South and Southeast Asian countries including Nepal, Sri Lanka, Burma, Thailand, Indonesia and Cambodia.Â The use of paper began only after the 10th century.

name: Ox Scapula Oracle Bone by ZhÄ“ng çˆ­
subject: oracle
description:
Oracle bone recording divinations by ZhÄ“ng çˆ­, one of the BÄ«n è³“ group of diviners from period I, corresponding to the reign of King Wu Ding (late Shang dynasty).

Oracle bones are pieces of ox scapula and turtle plastron which were used in pyromancy â€“ a form of divination â€“ during the Late Shang period (c.â€‰1250 â€“ c.â€‰1050 BCE) in ancient China. Scapulimancy is the specific term if ox scapulae were used for the divination, plastromancy if turtle plastrons were used. A recent count estimated that there were about 13,000 bones with a total of a little over 130,000 inscriptions in collections in China and some fourteen other countries.

Diviners would submit questions to deities regarding weather, crop planting, the fortunes of members of the royal family, military endeavors, and similar topics. These questions were carved onto the bone or shell in oracle bone script using a sharp tool. Intense heat was then applied with a metal rod until the bone or shell cracked due to thermal expansion. The diviner would then interpret the pattern of cracks and write the prognostication upon the piece as well. Pyromancy with bones continued in China into the Zhou dynasty, but the questions and prognostications were increasingly written with brushes and cinnabar ink, which degraded over time.

name: Bronze FÄng ZÅ«n Ritual Wine Container
description: A Chinese bronze 'fang zun' ritual wine container, from the Western Zhou Dynasty, dated c. 1000 BC, excavated in modern-day Luoyang. The written inscription cast in bronze on the vessel commemorates a gift of cowrie shells - currency in China at the time - to its owner from someone of presumed elite status in Zhou era society.

name: Dipylon inscription
subject: prize
description:
The Dipylon inscription is a short text written on an ancient Greek pottery vessel dated to c.â€‰740 BC. It is famous for being the oldest, or one of the oldest, known samples of the use of the Greek alphabet. The text is scratched on an oenochoe, which was found in 1871 and is named after the location where it was found, the ancient Dipylon Cemetery, near the Dipylon Gate on the area of Kerameikos in Athens.
The text marks the vessel as a prize in a dancing competition. It is translated as: 'whoever of the dancers now dances most lightly ...', and the second line is conjectured to have said something to the effect of '... he shall get this (vessel as his prize)'.

name: Edicts of Ashoka
subject: Buddhism
description:
TheÂ Edicts of AshokaÂ are a collection of more than thirty inscriptions on theÂ Pillars of Ashoka, as well as boulders and cave walls, attributed to EmperorÂ AshokaÂ of theÂ Maurya EmpireÂ who ruled most of theÂ Indian subcontinentÂ from 268 BCE to 232 BCE.Â Ashoka used the expressionÂ Dhaá¹ƒmaÂ LipiÂ (PrakritÂ in theÂ Brahmi script:Â ğ‘€¥ğ‘€ğ‘€«ğ‘€®ğ‘€ºğ‘€§ğ‘€º, â€˜Inscriptions of theÂ Dharmaâ€™) to describe his own Edicts.Â These inscriptions were dispersed throughout the areas of modern-dayÂ India,Â Bangladesh,Â Nepal,Â AfghanistanÂ andÂ Pakistan, and provide the first tangible evidence ofÂ Buddhism. The edicts describe in detailÂ Ashoka's policy on dhamma, an earnest attempt to solve some of the problems that a complex society faced.Â According to the edicts, the extent of his promotion ofÂ dhammaÂ during this period reached as far as the Greeks in theÂ MediterraneanÂ region. While the inscriptions mention the conversion of Ashoka to Buddhism, theÂ dhammaÂ that he promotes is largely ecumenical and non-sectarian in nature.

(This particular inscription is from a pillar from aÂ Major Pillar EdictÂ ofÂ Ashoka, inÂ Lauriya Araraj,Â Bihar,Â India)

name: Lead Piece from Pujol
period: Iberian Peninsula's pre-Roman era / Talaiotic period
subject: curse
source_url: From My Visit to Madrid Museum in February 2024
description: Levantine Iberian script. It has been interpreted as a possible execratio or curse on the enemies of the deceased
img_or_source2_url: Photo taken by me during my museum visit

name: Glyph Block 8 from San Bartolo
description: The ruins of San Bartolo, Guatemala, contain a sample of Maya hieroglyphic writing dating to the Late Preclassic period (400 B.C. to 200 A.D.). The writing appears on preserved painted walls and plaster fragments buried within the pyramidal structure known as â€œLas Pinturas,â€ which was constructed in discrete phases over several centuries. Samples of carbonized wood that are closely associated with the writing have calibrated radiocarbon dates of 200 to 300 B.C. This early Maya writing implies that a developed Maya writing system was in use centuries earlier than previously thought, approximating a time when we see the earliest scripts elsewhere in Mesoamerica.

name: Tao Te Ching (Mawangdui Silk Texts)
subject: Taoism
description:
TheÂ Mawangdui Silk TextsÂ (traditional Chinese:Â é¦¬ç‹å †å¸›æ›¸;Â simplified Chinese:Â é©¬ç‹å †å¸›ä¹¦;Â pinyin:Â MÇwÃ¡ngduÄ« BÃ³shÅ«) areÂ ChineseÂ philosophical and medical works written onÂ silkÂ which were discovered at theÂ MawangduiÂ site inÂ Changsha,Â Hunan, in 1973. They include some of the earliest attested manuscripts of existing texts (such as theÂ I Ching), two copies of theÂ Tao Te Ching, a copy ofÂ Zhan Guo Ce, works byÂ Gan DeÂ andÂ Shi Shen, and previously unknown medical texts such asÂ Wushi'er BingfangÂ (Prescriptions for Fifty-Two Ailments). Scholars arranged them into 28 types of silk books. Their approximately 120,000 words cover military strategy, mathematics, cartography, and the six classical arts: ritual, music, archery, horsemanship, writing, and arithmetic.

TheÂ Tao Te ChingÂ (traditional Chinese:Â é“å¾·ç¶“;Â simplified Chinese:Â é“å¾·ç») orÂ LaoziÂ is aÂ Chinese classic textÂ and foundational work ofÂ TaoismÂ traditionally credited to the sageÂ Laozi, though the text's authorship and date of composition and compilation are debated.Â The oldest excavated portion dates to the late 4th centuryÂ BC.

TheÂ Tao Te ChingÂ is central to both philosophical and religious Taoism, and has been highly influential toÂ Chinese philosophyÂ andÂ religious practiceÂ in general. It is generally taken as preceding theÂ Zhuangzi, the other core Taoist text.Â Terminology originating within the text has been reinterpreted and elaborated upon byÂ Legalist thinkers,Â Confucianists, and particularlyÂ Chinese Buddhists, which had been introduced to China significantly after the initial solidification of Taoist thought. The text is well known in the West, and is one of the most translated texts in world literature.

name: Rosetta Stone
subject: decree
description:
TheÂ Rosetta StoneÂ is aÂ steleÂ ofÂ granodioriteÂ inscribed with three versions of aÂ decree issued in 196 BCÂ during theÂ Ptolemaic dynastyÂ ofÂ Egypt, on behalf of KingÂ Ptolemy V Epiphanes. The top and middle texts are inÂ Ancient EgyptianÂ usingÂ hieroglyphicÂ andÂ DemoticÂ scripts, respectively, while the bottom is inÂ Ancient Greek. The decree has only minor differences across the three versions, making the Rosetta Stone key toÂ deciphering the Egyptian scripts.
The stone was carved during theÂ Hellenistic periodÂ and is believed to have originally been displayed within a temple, possibly atÂ Sais. It was probably moved in late antiquity or during theÂ Mamluk period, and was eventually used as building material in the construction ofÂ Fort JulienÂ near the town of Rashid (Rosetta) in theÂ Nile Delta. It was found there in July 1799 by French officerÂ Pierre-FranÃ§ois BouchardÂ during the NapoleonicÂ campaign in Egypt. It was the first Ancient Egyptian bilingual text recovered in modern times, and it aroused widespread public interest with its potential to decipher this previously untranslated hieroglyphic script. Lithographic copies and plaster casts soon began circulating among European museums and scholars. When the British defeated the French, they took the stone to London under the terms of theÂ Capitulation of AlexandriaÂ in 1801. Since 1802, it has been on public display at theÂ British MuseumÂ almost continuously and it is the most visited object there.

name: Great Psalms Scroll (11Q5) (Part of Dead Sea Scrolls)
subject: Christianity
description:
The Great Psalms Scroll, also referred to as 11Q5, is the most substantial and well preserved manuscript of Psalms of the thirty-seven discovered among the Dead Sea Scrolls in the Qumran caves. It is one of six Psalms manuscripts discovered in Cave 11.

The Dead Sea Scrolls, also called the Qumran Caves Scrolls, are a set of ancient Jewish manuscripts from the Second Temple period. They were discovered over a period of 10 years, between 1946 and 1956, at the Qumran Caves near Ein Feshkha in the West Bank, on the northern shore of the Dead Sea. Dating from the 3rd century BCE to the 1st century CE,[1] the Dead Sea Scrolls include the oldest surviving manuscripts of entire books later included in the biblical canons, including deuterocanonical manuscripts from late Second Temple Judaism and extrabiblical books. At the same time, they cast new light on the emergence of Christianity and of Rabbinic Judaism.[2] Almost all of the 15,000 scrolls and scroll fragments are held in the Shrine of the Book at the Israel Museum located in Jerusalem. The Israeli government's custody of the Dead Sea Scrolls is disputed by Jordan and the Palestinian Authority on territorial, legal, and humanitarian groundsâ€”they were mostly discovered following the Jordanian annexation of the West Bank and were acquired by Israel after Jordan lost the 1967 Arabâ€“Israeli War[3]â€”whilst Israel's claims are primarily based on historical and religious grounds, given their significance in Jewish history and in the heritage of Judaism.

name: Fragmentary Buddhist text - Gandhara birchbark scrolls
subject: Buddhism
description:
Fragmentary Buddhist text The manuscript is written on birchbark and is part of a group of early manuscripts from Gandhara (modern East Afghanistan/Noth-West Pakistan).

In 1994, the British Library acquired a group of some eighty Gandharan manuscript fragments from the first half of the 1st century CE, encompassing twentyâ€seven birchâ€bark scrolls.[9] These birch bark manuscripts were stored in clay jars, which preserved them. They are thought to have been found in western Pakistan, the location of Gandhara, buried in ancient monasteries. A team has been at work, trying to decipher the manuscripts: several volumes have appeared to date (see below). The manuscripts were written in the GÄndhÄrÄ« language using the Kharoá¹£á¹­hÄ« script and are therefore sometimes also called the Kharoá¹£á¹­hÄ« Manuscripts.

The collection is composed of a diversity of texts: a Dhammapada, discourses of the Buddha such as the Rhinoceros Sutra, avadanas and Purvayogas, commentaries and abhidharma texts.

name: Wooden Writing Tablet from Vindolanda
subject: birthday invitation
description:
The Vindolanda tablets are a set of wooden writing tablets from the Roman fort of Vindolanda in present-day Northumberland. The tablets comprise thin slices of wood around the size of postcards, on which was written cursive Latin using black ink. Most of the tablets date to around AD 100, during the reign of the emperor Trajan (AD 98â€“117). There are a smaller number of stylus tablets, which are thicker pieces of wood with a central recess for wax â€“ these were written on with a metal point, or 'stylus'. The writing on these only survives if the scribe pressed hard enough through the wax to leave an imprint on the wood, since the wax rarely survives.
â€¦ the tablets provide extraordinary insights into the social lives of officers and their families. The most famous example is the so-called birthday invitation, written by a woman called Claudia Severa, the wife of a fort commander named Aelius Brocchus. In the letter Severa invites her friend Sulpicia Lepidina, the wife of Vindolanda's fort commander, Flavius Cerialis, to her birthday party. She signs the letter in her own hand, writing 'I shall expect you sister. Farewell, sister, my dearest soul, as I hope to prosper, and hail'. Dated to around AD 100, this is the earliest example of a woman's handwriting from anywhere in the Roman Empire.

name: Svingerud Runestone (Svingerudsteinen)
subject: unknown
description:
TheÂ Svingerud RunestoneÂ is a sandstone object featuringÂ Elder FutharkÂ inscriptions found in a grave west ofÂ Oslo,Â Norway. Radiocarbon dating indicates that the grave and theÂ runestoneÂ date to between 1 and 250 CE, during theÂ Roman Iron Age, making it the oldest datable runestone known in the world, and potentially the oldest known runic inscription.Â The discovery is additionally notable for the content of its inscriptions.
The first three runes of the runic alphabet, áš  (f), áš¢ (u) and áš¦ (th), are found in one place on the stone, making this the earliest known occurrence of this sequence.
Eight runes are more legible than its other inscriptions; transliterated into Roman letters they spell eitherÂ idiberugÂ orÂ idiberun. According to Zilmer, â€˜The text may refer to a woman called Idibera and the inscription could mean 'For Idibera'. Other possibilities are that idiberug is the rendering of a name such as Idibergu, or perhaps the kin name Idiberung. And there are other possible interpretations â€“ as common with early runic inscriptions.â€™

name: Pi Yu Jing
subject: unknown
description:
Oldest surviving book on paper, 250 CE. The Phi YÃ¼ Ching on 'liu-ho' paper made in Liu-ho in northern Chiangsu. It is made from six different materials.
TheÂ Han dynastyÂ Chinese court officialÂ Cai LunÂ (c. 50â€“121 CE) is credited as the inventor of a method of papermaking (inspired by wasps and bees) using rags and other plant fibers in 105 CE.Â However, the discovery of specimens bearing writtenÂ Chinese charactersÂ in 2006 atÂ FangmatanÂ in north-east China'sÂ GansuÂ Province suggests that paper was in use by the ancient Chinese military more than 100 years before Cai, in 8 BCE, and possibly much earlier as the map fragment found at the Fangmatan tomb site dates from the early 2nd century BCE.Â It therefore would appear that â€˜Cai Lun's contribution was to improve this skill systematically and scientifically, fix a recipe for papermakingâ€™.

name: Bath Curse Tablet
subject: curse
description:
Curse tablet with complaint about the theft of Vilbia.

â€™May he who carried off Vilbia from me become liquid as the water. May she who so obscenely devoured her become dumbâ€™.

TheÂ Bath curse tabletsÂ are a collection of about 130Â RomanÂ eraÂ curse tabletsÂ (orÂ defixionesÂ inÂ Latin) discovered in 1979/1980 in the English city ofÂ Bath. The tablets were requests for intervention of the goddessÂ Sulis MinervaÂ in the return of stolen goods and to curse the perpetrators of the thefts. Inscribed mostly inÂ British Latin, they have been used to attest to the everyday spoken vernacular of theÂ Romano-BritishÂ population of the second to fourth centuries AD. They have also been recognised byÂ UNESCOÂ in itsÂ Memory of the World UK Register.

name: Birmingham Quran Manuscript
subject: Islam
description: TheÂ Birmingham Quran manuscriptÂ comprises two leaves ofÂ parchmentÂ from anÂ early Quranic manuscriptÂ orÂ muá¹£á¸¥af. In 2015, the manuscript, which is held by theÂ University of Birmingham,Â wasÂ radiocarbon datedÂ to between 568 and 645Â ADÂ (in the Islamic calendar, between 56 beforeÂ HijrahÂ and 24Â after Hijrah).Â It is presently believed that the manuscript is an early descendant of theÂ Uthmanic codex.Â It is part of theÂ Mingana CollectionÂ of Middle Eastern manuscripts, held by the university'sÂ Cadbury Research Library.

name: Diamond Sutra from Tang dynasty
subject: Buddhism
description: It is probably that this sutra, dated to 868 which makes it the earliest dated printed book in the world, was not printed in Dunhuang but in Sichuan, the southwest of China, where there was a thriving printing industry. It is clearly the product of a mature industry and it is believed that printing was invented in eighth-century China when someone experimented with carving a woodblock for a page of text rather than small Buddha stamps. Only a century after Wang Jie ordered the printing of this text Sichuan woodcarvers were employed to produce the first large-scale printing project in the world; the Buddhist Canon.

name: Missal of Silos
subject: Christianity
description:
TheÂ Missal of SilosÂ is the oldest known document onÂ paperÂ (as opposed toÂ parchment) created inÂ Europe; it dates to before 1080 AD.TheÂ manuscriptÂ was written onÂ quarto; it comprises 157Â folios, of which folios 1 to 37 are on paper and the rest are on parchment. Strictly speaking, it is not aÂ missal: It has been described as aÂ breviary-missal.Â It can also be described as aÂ Liber MysticusÂ orÂ Breviarum gothicum.
The missal is â€˜Codex 6â€™ held in the library of theÂ Monastery of Santo Domingo de SilosÂ nearÂ Burgos, Spain. While the codex is named after its long-term home in Silos, it was not made at the Silos monastery'sÂ scriptorium; it was made at the monastery ofÂ Santa MarÃ­a la Real of NÃ¡jera. The paper for the missal is believed to have been manufactured in Muslim-ruled territory (Al-Andalus),Â even thoughÂ NÃ¡jeraÂ was in Christian territory at the time the document was created
The manuscript relates to theÂ Mozarabic rite. This was suppressed in 1080 byÂ Pope Gregory VIIÂ (something which helps date the manuscript).However, the monastic library continued to hold a collection of liturgical manuscripts of the rite until the 19th century when some were sold.

name: Dresden Codex
found_region_origin: Likely YucatÃ¡n Peninsula (Mexico) but later found again in Dresden (Germany)

name: Birch-bark Letter No. 202
subject: doodle
description:
Birch-bark letter no.Â 202Â contains spelling lessons and drawings made by a boy namedÂ Onfim; based on craftsmanship, experts estimate his age as between 6 and 7 at the time.

AnthemiusÂ (Old Novgorodian:Â ĞĞ½Ñ³Ğ¸Ğ¼Ñ”,Â romanized:Â Onthime),Â better known by the modernÂ RussianÂ spelling of his name,Â OnfimÂ (Russian:Â ĞĞ½Ñ„Ğ¸Ğ¼), was a boy who lived inÂ NovgorodÂ (now Veliky Novgorod, Russia) in the 13th century, some time around 1220 or 1260. He left his notes and homework exercises scratched inÂ soft birch bark,Â which was preserved in the clay soil of Novgorod.

Onfim, who was most likely six or seven at the time, wrote in the East SlavicÂ Novgorod dialect. Besides letters and syllables, he drew 'battle scenes and drawings of himself and his teacher'.

name: Jikji
subject: Buddhism
description:
JikjiÂ (Korean:Â ì§ì§€ì‹¬ì²´ìš”ì ˆ) is the abbreviated title of aÂ Korean BuddhistÂ document whose title can be translated to â€˜Anthology of Great Buddhist Priests'Â ZenÂ Teachingsâ€™.Â Printed during theÂ GoryeoÂ Dynasty in 1377, it is the world's oldest extant book printed withÂ movable metal type.Â UNESCOÂ confirmedÂ JikjiÂ as the world's oldest metalloid type in September 2001 and includes it in theÂ Memory of the World Programme.

name: Gutenberg Bible (1 of 49 copies)
subject: Christianity
description:
TheÂ Gutenberg Bible, also known as theÂ 42-line Bible, theÂ Mazarin BibleÂ or theÂ B42, was the earliest majorÂ bookÂ printed in Europe using mass-produced metalÂ movable type. It marked the start of the Gutenberg Revolution and the age of printed books in the West. The book is valued and revered for its high aesthetic and artistic qualitiesÂ and its historical significance.

The Gutenberg Bible is an edition of the LatinÂ VulgateÂ printed in the 1450s byÂ Johannes GutenbergÂ inÂ MainzÂ (Holy Roman Empire), in present-dayÂ Germany. Out of either 158 or 180 copies that were originally printed, 49 survive in at least substantial portion, 21 of them in entirety. They are thought to be among the world's most valuable books, although no complete copy has been sold since 1978. In March 1455, the futureÂ Pope Pius IIÂ wrote that he had seen pages from the Gutenberg Bible displayed inÂ FrankfurtÂ to promote the edition.
